commander.name: Major-General George Erskine
commander.previous_service: Replaced Major-General John Harding who was wounded in December 1942. Previously commanded 43rd (Wessex) Infantry Division. Led division through final Tunisia Campaign Jan-May 1943.
commander.notes: Erskine took command when Harding was wounded by shell. Led division from Tripolitania into Tunisia, participating in Battle of Mareth Line (20-27 March 1943), Battle of Wadi Akarit (6-7 April 1943), and final Tunisia battles April-May 1943.

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia (entered Tunisia 16 February 1943 crossing from Libya)

Sherman M4.notes: 75mm gun. Sherman deliveries increased through Tripoli port (captured 23 January 1943). Main battle tank for Tunisia Campaign.

Sherman M4A2.notes: Diesel-engine variant. Improved operational range for Tunisia operations.

Crusader III.notes: 6-pounder (57mm) gun. Being supplemented by Shermans but still in frontline service.

Stuart M3 'Honey'.notes: 37mm gun. Reconnaissance and light squadrons. Reliable in Tunisia terrain.

Stuart M5.notes: Improved Stuart variant with twin Cadillac engines. Arriving in increasing numbers.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Mk II.notes: Two field regiments (24 guns each) - 3rd RHA and 5th RHA. Standard British field gun with excellent range and versatility.

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).notes: Anti-tank regiment. Effective against German Panzer III and IV tanks. 2-pounders mostly phased out by Q1 1943.

Ordnance QF 2-pounder (40mm).notes: Portee-mounted. Nearly phased out, limited numbers remaining.

Bofors 40mm.notes: Light anti-aircraft battery. Mobile Bofors guns for divisional air defense.

supply_logistics.supply_status: Improved significantly with Tripoli port operational (captured 23 Jan 1943). Supply lines now 600-800km vs 1800km during Libyan pursuit. Tunisia terrain more forgiving with better roads. Main constraint: ammunition for expected intensive battles against German defenses at Mareth Line and Wadi Akarit. Fuel adequate for operations. Water more available in Tunisia vs Libyan desert.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Mixed terrain - coastal plain, hills, wadis, and rocky plateau (Southern Tunisia)

subordinate_units.composition: 1st Royal Tank Regiment (RTR), 5th RTR, 4th County of London Yeomanry (CLY/Sharpshooters), 1st Rifle Brigade (Motor Battalion)
subordinate_units.notes: Main striking force. Equipped primarily with Sherman and Crusader tanks. Experienced brigade that fought at El Alamein and throughout Libya pursuit.

subordinate_units.composition: 1/5th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/6th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment, 1/7th Battalion Queen's Royal Regiment
subordinate_units.notes: Motor infantry brigade. Three battalions of Queen's Royal Regiment providing infantry support for armoured operations. Fought at Mareth Line and Wadi Akarit.

subordinate_units.composition: Royal Scots Greys, 4th Hussars (Queen's Own), 8th Hussars (King's Royal Irish), 2nd Derbyshire Yeomanry (reconnaissance)
subordinate_units.notes: Reconnaissance brigade. 4th and 8th Hussars operating as separate regiments again after temporary amalgamation ended. Primarily Stuart light tanks and armoured cars.
Mobile field artillery. Self-propelled support for armoured operations.
Second field artillery regiment. Provided fire support during Tunisia Campaign.
Divisional anti-tank defense. Primarily 6-pounder guns by Q1 1943, 2-pounders phased out.

subordinate_units.composition: Communications squadrons, wireless sections, line sections
Field squadrons, workshop sections, bridging sections
subordinate_units.notes: Mine clearance, bridging, demolitions. Critical for Tunisia terrain.

subordinate_units.composition: Transport companies, supply columns, petrol company, water company
subordinate_units.notes: Royal Army Service Corps. Logistics support with improved supply lines via Tripoli.

tactical_doctrine.role: Elite mobile armoured division. Primary role: breakthrough operations, exploitation, pursuit, and reconnaissance in force. 'Desert Rats' reputation established through continuous combat 1940-1943 in North Africa.
special_capabilities: Experienced in fighting German Afrika Korps
tactical_innovations: Mixed tank squadrons (Sherman heavy + Stuart light)
Motor infantry integration with armoured brigades
Radio net coordination for dispersed operations
known_issues: Tank mechanical reliability on long marches
Sherman vulnerability to German 88mm and Pak 40 guns
Tunisia terrain more restrictive than open desert
Coordination with US forces (different doctrine and equipment)
Minefields and defensive positions favor defenders
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive North Africa combat experience: sun compasses, sand channels, condensers, extra water/fuel stowage, desert camouflage, goggles and respirators, specialized navigation. Division pioneered desert warfare 1940-1942. Adapting to Tunisia mixed terrain Q1 1943.

scenario_suitability: Combined operations with First Army and US II Corps
special_rules: Desert Rats: +1 morale, elite unit status
Veteran Division: Reroll failed morale checks once per game
Combined Arms Mastery: Artillery and tank coordination +10%
Tank Gunnery: +5% hit probability for Sherman tanks
Night Operations: No penalty for night movement
Reconnaissance Excellence: +15% spotting range for armoured cars
Improved Supply: Supply radius +20% with Tripoli port operational
historical_engagements: Battle of Medenine (6 March 1943 - defensive role)

source: British Military History - 7th Armoured Division Tunisia Campaign (Primary, 90% confidence)
TM 30-410: Handbook on the British Army 1942 (US War Department, 88% confidence)
Battle Orders 028: Desert Rats - British 8th Army in North Africa 1941-43 (Osprey, 90% confidence)
Nafziger Collection: 943AEAA - Allied Forces North Africa Theater 13 May 1943 (85% confidence)
British Armoured Division War Establishment 1943 (Primary, 92% confidence)
Unit War Diaries - 7th Armoured Division Q1 1943 (Primary via secondary sources, 85% confidence)
Historical Atlas of World War II (DK Publishing, Secondary, 75% confidence)
known_gaps: Exact tank distribution by regiment (allocated proportionally)
Most subordinate unit commander names except brigade commanders
Precise operational vs total tank strength (estimated 91% operational)
Detailed support vehicle breakdown within RASC companies
Chief of Staff name not found in sources
Individual regiment/battalion reference files not yet created
validation.notes: Data compiled from British armoured division establishment tables, historical records, and unit histories. Personnel strength 14,920 based on 1943 establishment with full reinforcements via Tripoli. Tank strength increased to 178 (vs 172 in Q4 1942) with improved Sherman deliveries. Supply situation dramatically improved with Tripoli port operational (600-800km vs 1800km supply line). Division participated in Mareth Line, Wadi Akarit, and final Tunisia battles. Commander changed from Harding (wounded Dec 1942) to Erskine (7 Jan 1943).
